Fiction
I KNOW THIS MUCH IS TRUE, by Wally Lamb. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $27.50.) A troubled man must cope with his schizophrenic identical-twin brother.
THE KLONE AND I, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A woman believes she has found Mr. Right, a high-tech expert, then is amazed to meet his clone.
SUMMER SISTERS, by Judy Blume. (Delacorte, $21.95.) Coming of age on Martha's Vineyard.
BRIDGET JONES's DIARY, by Helen Fielding. (Viking, $22.95.) A year in the life of a single woman in London.
UNSPEAKABLE, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $25.) A psychotic killer, returning to his Texas hometown to wreak vengeance, uses a troubled widow as his pawn.
A WIDOW FOR ONE YEAR, by John Irving. (Random House, $27.95.) Three looks at the complex emotional life of a writer and single mother.

LOW COUNTRY, by Anne Rivers Siddons. (HarperCollins, $25.) A South Carolina woman's life reaches a crisis when her husband is forced to consider turning the island she inherited and cherishes into a resort.
MESSAGE IN A BOTTLE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $20.) After finding a seaborne bottle containing an enigmatic letter, a divorced woman encounters love.
THE STREET LAWYER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A young lawyer comes to terms with himself after discovering his prestigious firm's dirty secret.
MEMOIRS OF A GEISHA, by Arthur Golden. (Knopf, $25.) The life of a young woman in wartime Kyoto.
COLD MOUNTAIN, by Charles Frazier. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) A wounded Confederate soldier journeys home toward the end of the Civil War.
*THE LAST FULL MEASURE, by Jeff Shaara. (Ballantine, $25.95.) The final years of the Civil War.
THE ELEVENTH COMMANDMENT, by Jeffrey Archer. (HarperCollins, $26.) A C.I.A. officer must contend with a new enemy, the Director of Central Intelligence.
QUITE A YEAR FOR PLUMS, by Bailey White. (Knopf, $22.) Life as lived by the eccentric inhabitants of a small Georgia town.
YOU BELONG TO ME, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A radio talk-show host undertakes to expose a killer who targets lonely women.
*SUNSET LIMITED, by James Lee Burke. (Doubleday, $24.95.) After a photojournalist returns to her Louisiana hometown, Detective Dave Robicheaux investigates her father's murder 40 years before.

Nonfiction
A PIRATE LOOKS AT FIFTY, by Jimmy Buffett. (Random House, $24.95.) While traveling from the Florida Keys to the Amazon, the singer-songwriter reflects on his half-century of life.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
A MONK SWIMMING, by Malachy McCourt. (Hyperion, $23.95.) The writer and actor (and brother of Frank McCourt) recalls his life in America and Ireland.
A WALK IN THE WOODS, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $25.) A journalist finds beauty and humor while hiking the Appalachian Trail.
ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $25.) An Irish-American writer remembers his childhood amid the miseries of Limerick.
TITAN, by Ron Chernow. (Random House, $30.) The life of John D. Rockefeller Sr.
WE ARE OUR MOTHERS' DAUGHTERS, by Cokie Roberts. (Morrow, $19.95.) The television news anchor's personal reflections on women in politics and business and as mothers, wives, sisters and friends.
THE MILLIONAIRE NEXT DOOR, by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko. (Longstreet, $22.) An analysis of the lives of wealthy Americans. (+)
THE GIFTS OF THE JEWS, by Thomas Cahill. (Talese/ Doubleday, $23.50.) What Western civilization owes an ancient nomadic tribe.

SHIP OF GOLD IN THE DEEP BLUE SEA, by Gary Kinder. (Atlantic Monthly, $27.50.) An account of the wreck of a side-wheeler off the Carolina coast in 1857 and the efforts of a group to recover its treasure in 1989.
THE MAN WHO LISTENS TO HORSES, by Monty Roberts. (Random House, $23.) The memoirs of a professional horse trainer.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random House, $25.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga. (+)
PHILISTINES AT THE HEDGEROW, by Steven Gaines. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) A social history of the East End of Long Island, haunt of the rich and celebrated.
*CONVERSATIONS WITH GOD: Book 1, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam, $19.95.) The author addresses questions of good and evil, guilt and sin. (+)
STILL ME, by Christopher Reeve. (Random House, $25.) The stage and film actor looks back at his life, especially since his crippling accident three years ago.

An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.
And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

ANNALS OF THE FORMER WORLD, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) The history of the whole earth as elucidated from America's rockscape, containing four previous books plus a section on the Midwest, all performed at great length yet with becoming modesty.

BE SWEET: A Conditional Love Story, by Roy Blount Jr. (Knopf, $24.) A raucous, funny memoir but a heartbreaker as well, an effort, by a writer who is both literary and down-home, to deal with memories of a difficult (and sometimes opaque) mother and of an awkward childhood in Georgia.

BLOOD AND VENGEANCE: One Family's Story of the War in Bosnia, by Chuck Sudetic. (Norton, $26.95.) An eloquent inspection of war, its crimes and their causes, pursued through several generations of a Bosnian Muslim family; by a Croatian-American journalist who covered the Balkan war for The New York Times.

CUPID AND DIANA, by Christina Bartolomeo. (Scribner, $22.) A wry and provoking novel, set in Washington, in which, for a change, it's the women (including the narrator) who are into cheating, infidelity and the sacrifice of love to business.

THE LAST RESORT, by Alison Lurie. (Holt, $22.) The place the world ends in this sparkling, smart novel is Key West, where a number of exemplary type characters have to stop and wait for whatever they are running from to catch up.

MISSING WOMEN AND OTHERS: Stories, by June Spence. (Riverhead, $21.95.) Evocative short stories in most of which women (sometimes men) seem mired in perpetual states of transition: recent divorce, recovery from crackup, boring jobs; the author's first collection.

MY HEART LAID BARE, by Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $26.95.) A certain vanity of soul, a belief in a special American national destiny, makes this novel's inhabitants easy marks for greed, racism and the workings of a cosmic con artist with a resemblance to Satan.

PARK CITY: New and Selected Stories, by Ann Beattie. (Knopf, $25.) Three dozen fine stories, warm and cool at once, from 25 years of writing about men and women for whom domestic rupture occurs quietly, ordinarily and inevitably.

ROXANNA SLADE, by Reynolds Price. (Scribner, $25.) A woman in her 90's passes judgments on the century and concludes that life itself is ''an adequate blessing'' in this novel by a writer more receptive to grace than is usual in these times.

VAIN EMPIRES: Poems, by William Logan. (Penguin, paper, $14.95.) A brilliant, cheerless performance whose prevailing spirit is an atmosphere of anger, sadness and disgust; many poems are meditations on mankind's historical enterprises, earthly, spiritual or intellectual.
